Disembrangling Programming

April 19-25 status

Tags: mozilla, webdev, weekly updates
25 Apr 2010

Last week (April 19-25)

  • kitsune

    • r?d adding sumo-dev to receive useful stack traces from kitsune
    • r?d improved maintenance of locales, go James!
    • r?d kitsune documentation
    • r?d better handling of timeouts for excerpts and merged
    • r?d unicode improvements, adding sumo.utils.urlencode and merged
    • r?d fixing an IE6/7 bug
    • r?d case insensitive Accept-Language for Opera, Chrome, Safari
    • r?d adding a search plugin
    • fix pagination on IE6
    • adding two new supported locales
    • finished lots of tests for search filters and JSON for all
    • finished the remaining 2.0 bugs with the rest of the SUMOdev team
    • installed mod_wsgi locally with help of James’ docs
    • assisted with IT bugs to convert the database to UTF8 according to this bug
    • debugging server issues for kitsune stage
    • begin work on milestone 2.1

  • tiki

    • r?d using kitsune for search on stage-new
    • filed patch for adding WebTrends to SUMO for tracking
    • revert a notifications bug for articles
    • add .htaccess rewrites for Fx3.7 help topic: keyboard shortcuts
    • debugging screencast bug on mobile

This week (April 26-30)

  • WebDev onsite! Excited to hang out with the team.

  • kitsune

    • work on forums and other 2.1 stuff
    • prepare for kitsune push, potential QA bugs

  • tiki

    • prepare for 1.5.4 push, potential QA bugs
    • figure out screencast bug

I am the Co-founder and CTO of SoWink Inc., a revolutionary social online-dating service. Be sure to check out our blog for more about us.

Until April 2011, I worked as a web developer for Mozilla, with main focus on Django, Python, and PHP. Occasionally, I write tutorials or post other information I find interesting.

I enjoy doing freelance work for other websites, mostly non-profits. If you're interested in my services, contact me through one of the links below.

Follow me -- Email me -- My GitHub

Success is a journey, not a destination. The doing is often more important than the outcome. — Arthur Robert Ashe, Jr
